When I arranged your text, I left the important thing, removing the bias of your original writing. This is: The support of the upper classes to Felipe II and of the majority of the people to the prior. The proclamation of Felipe II as King of Portugal by the Cortes of Tomar with the name of Felipe I. However, I do not understand the stubbornness to preserve a clearly non-neutral text such as: There was no Castilian occupation because the campaign was quick and direct towards Lisbon, so the kingdom could not be occupied. The king already had the support of the upper classes, so the army did not assure anything. Finally, a phrase like "the overwhelming majority of the people" is clearly non-neutral. So please stop trying to impose a biased view of history and read WP: PVN. Thanks.

Hi Blady. I've been checking the article: the first time it was deleted because it was copied from a web page, which violated copyright. The other times because he violated one of the wiki's policies: the one that requires neutrality. I imagine this is due to this paragraph: The best you can do is write it neutrally, without praise or disqualification, taking the data from the web (just the data, then you write it your way) and placing it as a reference in a section of external links. If you find more references that is a relevant person, whose biography should appear in an encyclopedia, place them as well. If you need help, come back to my page whenever you want. PS: One thing: to sign Blady Morfin, because the link leads to an article, not to a user page: User: Blady Morfin. The way to sign is to put ~~~~, or easier: click on this button Image: Signature icon.png from the toolbar that appears when editing.

Dear Poverino, According to the Rae, the names of works of art or artistic concepts can be translated or not, if you choose not to translate them, they should always be in italics, to indicate that it is foreignism. So far the norm. However, in general, it is chosen to translate the name of more classical works or that already have an extensive bibliography (for example "The Birth of Venus") and the more contemporary or less known works are usually left in their original language (the Rauschenberg Combines). The same happens with the sites, Casa Blanca is translated, but La Défense does not. If you are looking to homogenize the article, I would recommend that you continue translating the names of the works, if any translation squeaks a bit (such as Barrios Españoles), you could leave the original name. Nor should we fall into the absurdity of completely translating everything, but the Queens neighborhood in NY would be the Queens neighborhood! In any case, good luck with the magnificent work you are doing! Cordially, Enric de

The name of República Srpska is a linguistic aberration, say the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Complutense University or the sursum corda. It's like saying Federal Republic of Deutschland. The name of the Serbian Republic is confusing, but correct. The problem can be solved with the name Serbian Republic (of Bosnia-Herzegovina). In any case, it is not our fault that the Serbian name violates the alleged rights of Bosnians or Croats - after all, srpska means the same thing, only that the majority of Spaniards do not know it. It's like refusing to call China the People's Republic of China, just because Tibetans, Manchu, and so on also live there. It is not our business to do justice to the language: only translate. On the other hand, it seems incredible to me that the Complutense University does not know that, if Srpska is a noun as well as an adjective in Serbian, exactly the same thing happens with Serbia in Spanish.
